error.signature: Too many re-renders. React limits the number of renders to prevent an infinite loop.
error.regex: Too many re-renders.*React limits the number of renders|Cannot update during an existing state transition

verdict.summary: setState called directly in the render body (not inside useEffect or event handler) causes immediate re-render which calls setState again, creating an infinite loop.

dead_ends.action: Add a condition check around the setState call in the render body
dead_ends.why_fails: If the condition ever evaluates to true during render, the loop restarts; does not address the root cause of calling setState during render

dead_ends.action: Use useRef to gate the setState call
dead_ends.why_fails: Adds complexity without fixing the architecture; ref mutations during render are unpredictable in concurrent mode

workarounds.action: Move the setState call into a useEffect
Derive the value during render instead of using setState
workarounds.how: Replace useState + setState-in-render with const derivedValue = useMemo(() => compute(props), [props]);
workarounds.condition: When the state is purely derived from props or other state

leads_to.condition: When the infinite loop is not caught early enough by React's bail-out

preceded_by.condition: When attempting to fix cross-component render update by moving setState into the local render body

frequently_confused_with.distinction: react-bad-setstate-in-render focuses on setState called directly in the render function body, while too-many-rerenders can also be caused by event handler references like onClick={handler()} instead of onClick={handler}
